data.title: Pictures of Julia Grant Cantacuzene and Her Descendants
data.meta_description: Information about General and President Ulysses S. Grant and resources for doing  research. Includes material suitable for the K-12 audience.
data.text:
The Library of Congress has this dated as December 23, 1921. The Fayetteville Observer, January 14, 1922, reports that Julia was the Chair of the American Central Committee for Russian Relief, aiding Russian refugees driven out of their country by the Bolsheviks. Her office is in the same room that Grant occupied as Secretary of War, in the old War Building, 532 17th St. NW., Washington, DC. Grant's portrait hangs behind her.

Clarissa Pelham Curtis, first wife of Julia and Prince Michael's first child, their son Michael who was born in 1900. This picture is from the Miami Herald, July 14, 1921.

Michael and Julia Grant Cantacuzene's first daughter, born 1904. From the New York Tribune, November 13, 1921. She was 17 in this picture.

Michael and Julia Grant Cantacuzene's first daughter, born 1904. From around the time of her second marriage to William Durrell Siebern, newspaper article dated January 6, 1935, Omaha Sunday Bee.

Clarissa Pelham Curtis, first wife of Julia and Prince Michael's first child, their son Michael who was born in 1900. This picture is from the Boston Herald July 1921, at the time of her engagement to Michael.

Clarissa Pelham Curtis, first wife of Julia and Prince Michael's first child, their son Michael who was born in 1900. This picture is from the Pittsburgh Press, June 19, 1921, at the time of her engagement to Michael.

"Although the "official" wedding of Prince Michael Cantacuzene and Miss Clarissa Curtis of this city does not take place until tomorrow at Nahant, a religious ceremony in accordance with the Russian Orthodox rites of the Greek Catholic Church was performed this afternoon..." New York Times, June 27, 1921. Picture from the New York Herald.

From History of the Daughters of the American Revolution of Florida, 1892/1933, volume 1. Jacksonville, Florida, 1933, pp. 259-261. Julia Grant Cantacuzene was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution based on her great great grandfather Noah's service, which is fictitious.

Clarissa Pelham Curtis, first wife of Julia and Prince Michael's first child, their son Michael who was born in 1900. This picture is from the Ogden Standard, May 17, 1921, at the time of her engagement to Michael.

Clarissa Pelham Curtis and Prince Michael Cantacuzene at the time of their engagement. From the Owensboro, Kentucky Messenger-Inquirer, May 1, 1921. I cannot find any explanation for the hat with the red cross on it. Red cross uniforms from the 1920s included headgear that looked like this.
